legacy: Phidias is regarded as one of the greatest sculptors of Ancient Greece, most famous for his work on the Parthenon and the Statue of Zeus at Olympia.
educationOrTraining: Trained under the sculptor Ageladas

legacy: Widely considered one of the most diversely talented individuals ever, shaping both art and science.
educationOrTraining: Apprentice to Andrea del Verrocchio in Florence

legacy: Michelangelo is widely regarded as one of the most influential artists in Western art history, and his works embody the ideals of the Renaissance.
educationOrTraining: Apprentice to Domenico Ghirlandaio, studied at the Medici Gardens in Florence

legacy: Raphael is known for his graceful and harmonious compositions, and he was one of the leading figures of the High Renaissance.
educationOrTraining: Apprentice to Pietro Perugino, influenced by Leonardo and Michelangelo

placeOfBirth: Pieve di Cadore, Republic of Venice
legacy: Titian was a master of color and light, shaping the course of Venetian painting and influencing generations of artists.
educationOrTraining: Apprentice to Giovanni Bellini, later worked alongside Giorgione

legacy: Caravaggio revolutionized Baroque painting with his use of chiaroscuro, influencing many artists and changing the way light and shadow were used in art.
educationOrTraining: Apprentice to Simone Peterzano in Milan

legacy: Rubens is known for his dynamic compositions, emotional intensity, and mastery of color and movement, and he played a central role in the development of Baroque art.
educationOrTraining: Studied in Antwerp and Italy, worked under the influence of Italian Renaissance artists

legacy: Velázquez is considered one of the greatest painters in Spanish history, known for his innovative and naturalistic approach to portraiture and mastery of light and space.
educationOrTraining: Apprenticed to Francisco Pacheco in Seville

notableWorks: The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp
legacy: Rembrandt is one of the most renowned painters and etchers in European art history, known for his masterful use of light, shadow, and his intimate portrayals of subjects.
educationOrTraining: Apprenticed to Pieter Lastman in Amsterdam

legacy: Vermeer is celebrated for his use of light, his serene domestic scenes, and his ability to capture intimate, quiet moments, which have made his works enduringly popular.
educationOrTraining: Little is known, possibly trained by a local artist or in the workshop of Pieter de Hooch

notableWorks: The Sleep of Reason Produces Monsters
legacy: Goya's dark and politically charged works helped pave the way for modern art, capturing the emotional and social turmoil of his time.
educationOrTraining: Apprenticed to Francisco Bayeu in Zaragoza

legacy: Delacroix was a leading figure in Romanticism, known for his emotional intensity and bold use of color, deeply influencing future generations of artists.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris

legacy: Turner was a pioneering force in atmospheric landscapes, influencing both Romanticism and Impressionism with his innovative use of light and color.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Royal Academy of Arts in London

legacy: Monet is the founder of Impressionism, famous for his focus on light, color, and the fleeting qualities of the natural world.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Le Havre Art School and later at the Académie Suisse in Paris

legacy: Degas is famous for his works depicting modern life, especially ballet dancers, and his innovative approach to movement and composition.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris

legacy: Cézanne is regarded as the forefather of modern art, bridging the gap between Impressionism and Cubism with his bold use of color and form.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the École des Beaux-Arts in Aix-en-Provence

legacy: Van Gogh is known for his emotionally intense and vibrant works, which have become some of the most iconic in art history, influencing Expressionism and modern art.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp and various art schools

notableWorks: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte
legacy: Seurat developed Pointillism, an innovative technique based on applying small dots of color, which became a major influence in the Post-Impressionist movement.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris

legacy: Matisse was a leading figure in Fauvism, known for his bold use of color and fluid shapes, making a profound impact on modern art and visual language.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris

legacy: Picasso revolutionized art with his pioneering work in Cubism and his ability to break traditional representations, leaving a lasting legacy in modern and contemporary art.
educationOrTraining: Studied at various art schools, including the Royal Academy of San Fernando in Madrid

legacy: Braque, alongside Picasso, co-founded Cubism, revolutionizing visual representation and influencing movements such as abstract art and modernism.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris

legacy: Kandinsky is considered one of the pioneers of abstract art, exploring the emotional potential of colors and shapes, and his theories greatly influenced modern art.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the University of Moscow, later at the Academy of Fine Arts in Munich

legacy: Malevich was the founder of Suprematism, pioneering minimalist abstraction and exploring the spiritual and philosophical possibilities of pure geometric forms.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Moscow School of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture

influences: Marcel Duchamp's own philosophy of art
legacy: Duchamp is considered the father of conceptual art, challenging traditional ideas of art and its role in society, famously with his readymades like 'Fountain'.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Académie Julian in Paris

notableWorks: Composition II in Red, Blue, and Yellow
legacy: Mondrian was a pioneer of abstract art, known for his geometric abstraction and the development of the De Stijl movement, emphasizing balance and harmony through basic shapes and primary colors.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Academy of Art in Amsterdam

notableWorks: The Sacrament of the Last Supper
legacy: Dalí was a key figure in Surrealism, known for his dreamlike, bizarre imagery and his exploration of the subconscious mind. His work continues to influence contemporary surrealist art.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts of San Fernando

legacy: Magritte is known for his witty and thought-provoking surrealist imagery, often questioning the nature of reality and perception, most famously in 'The Treachery of Images'.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Brussels

notableWorks: Self-Portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird
legacy: Kahlo's personal and emotive works, often exploring pain, identity, and Mexican culture, have made her a feminist icon and a major figure in modern art.
educationOrTraining: Self-taught, with influences from Diego Rivera

legacy: Pollock revolutionized abstract art with his drip painting technique, using spontaneous, chaotic brushstrokes to express emotion and the unconscious mind.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Art Students League in New York

legacy: Rothko's meditative color-focused works are a hallmark of the Color Field Painting movement, with an emphasis on emotional depth through large, luminous blocks of color.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Art Students League in New York

legacy: Warhol became a leading figure in the Pop Art movement, using mass-production techniques and celebrity culture to blur the lines between high and low art.
educationOrTraining: Studied at Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie Mellon University)

legacy: Lichtenstein’s comic strip-inspired art brought a new level of sophistication to popular culture, elevating mundane imagery into high art with his signature Ben-Day dots.
educationOrTraining: Studied at Ohio State University, then the Art Students League of New York

legacy: Kusama’s immersive installations and the use of polka dots and infinity rooms have made her a key figure in contemporary art, reflecting themes of repetition and infinity.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Kyoto City University of Arts

notableWorks: Boy and Dog in a Johnnypump
legacy: Basquiat’s vibrant, raw works are known for their social commentary and exploration of race, identity, and power, making him a key figure in the Neo-Expressionism movement.
educationOrTraining: Self-taught, influenced by street art

notableWorks: The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife
legacy: Hokusai is one of the most influential artists of the Edo period, and his iconic print 'The Great Wave off Kanagawa' has become one of the most recognized works in the world.
educationOrTraining: Apprenticed to Katsukawa Shunshō, later influenced by Western art techniques

legacy: Ai Weiwei is a globally recognized figure in contemporary art, known for his political activism and conceptual works that challenge societal norms, especially regarding freedom of expression.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Beijing Film Academy, later studied in the United States at Parsons The New School for Design

legacy: Hadid was the first woman to win the Pritzker Architecture Prize, and her futuristic, fluid designs transformed modern architecture with their dynamic, curvilinear forms.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London

legacy: Rodin is considered the father of modern sculpture, known for his expressive and innovative approach to form and movement, particularly in works like 'The Thinker'.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris

legacy: Calder is renowned for his invention of the mobile, creating dynamic sculptures that use movement as a key component. His works revolutionized modern sculpture by incorporating motion into static art.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Stevens Institute of Technology and the Art Students League of New York

legacy: Hepworth was a leading figure in British modern sculpture, known for her abstract, organic forms. She helped shape 20th-century sculpture, focusing on the relationship between sculpture and its environment.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Leeds School of Art and the Royal College of Art in London

legacy: Adams was a pioneering landscape photographer, known for his stunning black-and-white images of the American West. His work has had a lasting impact on environmental photography and the conservation movement.
educationOrTraining: Self-taught in photography, studied at the San Francisco Institute of Art

legacy: Sherman is best known for her conceptual portraits, often exploring themes of identity, gender, and the media. Her self-portraits, where she assumes various characters, have become iconic in contemporary photography.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the State University of New York at Buffalo

placeOfBirth: Heraklion, Kingdom of Candia (now Crete, Greece)
notableWorks: The Burial of the Count of Orgaz
legacy: El Greco is known for his distinctive style that blends Byzantine traditions with Renaissance elements. His use of elongated forms and spiritual intensity greatly influenced later artists, including expressionists.
educationOrTraining: Studied in Venice and Rome, influenced by Titian and Michelangelo

legacy: Klimt is one of the most prominent figures of Symbolism and the Vienna Secession, celebrated for his elaborate decorative style and the sensual, golden imagery of works like 'The Kiss'.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Academy of Fine Arts in Vienna

legacy: Munch is renowned for his exploration of psychological themes such as anxiety, death, and human existence, particularly through his iconic work 'The Scream'. His emotional intensity had a lasting impact on the Expressionist movement.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Royal School of Art and Design in Oslo

notableWorks: Portrait of an Artist (Pool with Two Figures)
legacy: Hockney is one of the most influential contemporary artists, known for his bright, colorful works and playful approach to painting. His depictions of California pools and landscapes are iconic in the art world.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Royal Academy of Arts in London

legacy: Bourgeois is known for her deeply personal and psychological sculptures, exploring themes of trauma, sexuality, and the family. Her works are a crucial part of the feminist and modern art movements.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the École du Louvre and the Académie de la Grande Chaumière

legacy: Haring's bold, symbolic works captured the energy of the 1980s urban art scene. His use of bright colors and simple, cartoon-like characters became iconic in the graffiti and street art movements.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the School of Visual Arts in New York

notableWorks: Songs of Innocence and of Experience
The Marriage of Heaven and Hell
legacy: Blake was a visionary poet and artist whose works combined mysticism with deeply personal themes. His revolutionary blend of poetry and visual art laid the foundations for both Romanticism and Symbolism.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Royal Academy of Arts in London

legacy: Le Corbusier was a pioneer of modern architecture, known for his innovative use of concrete, open floor plans, and the development of the principles of functionalism. His designs transformed architecture globally, and his concepts remain influential.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the La Chaux-de-Fonds Art School and in Paris with various architects

legacy: John Constable is one of the most famous landscape painters in English art history. His work revolutionized the depiction of the English countryside, capturing its natural beauty with great attention to light, atmosphere, and detail. His paintings had a profound influence on later generations of artists, particularly the French Impressionists.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Royal Academy Schools in London

placeOfBirth: Vitebsk, Belarus (then part of the Russian Empire)
legacy: Marc Chagall was a pioneering 20th-century artist whose work integrated Jewish folklore, religious symbolism, and vibrant color. His unique visual language combined elements of Surrealism and Expressionism, leaving a profound mark on modern art. Chagall's contributions span across painting, stained glass, ceramics, and theater sets.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Imperial Society for the Protection of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg, Russia

notableWorks: The Enigma of an Autumn Afternoon
The Mystery and Melancholy of a Street
legacy: Giorgio de Chirico is best known for founding the Metaphysical art movement, which featured eerie, dreamlike imagery, often incorporating classical architecture, enigmatic figures, and vast, empty spaces. His work had a significant influence on the Surrealist movement and continues to be admired for its symbolic and atmospheric qualities.
educationOrTraining: Studied at the Athens School of Fine Arts and later in Munich, Germany

legacy: Henri Rousseau, a self-taught artist, is renowned for his naive, dreamlike depictions of lush jungles, exotic animals, and mysterious landscapes. His work, often considered primitive due to its lack of formal training, had a significant influence on the Surrealist movement and continues to be admired for its imaginative and fantastical qualities.
educationOrTraining: Self-taught
